Desc: Crop identifier. Options include corn, soy bean, oats/legume, and hay.

Notes: Taken from ISU's estimated production cost.

Under such contracts, a farmer delivers grain to an elevator but does not establish a price with the elevator until a later date chosen by the farmer. This is the cost associated with paying the local elevator to store one's grain until it is sold.
Taken from ISU's estimated production cost.

Desc: Cost of applying manure to fields.

Notes: Taken from Iowa Farm business records.

Desc: Cost of moving and storing hay bales.

Notes: Traditional crops stored for 3 months, sold at first of the year. Thompson crops stored on the farm and fed to livestock.
Net revenue? Or total revenue?  Page 7-6 makes this seem like total revenue b/c they talk about then factoring in labor savings

Desc: Price per bushel or pound of individual crops.
Crop yields per Acre in bushels or pounds.
Notes: Based on actual yield from Thompson farm or conventional Boone county average corn and soy bean yields.

Desc: Total expenses divided by yield (Cost per bushel or pound).

Notes: Labor cost/return computed at 7-8 dollars/hour times field time (25 percent added to field time for travel and repairs.) Pertains to the wages Dick (the farmer) paid himself for the work he was doing (or the work his neighbor was doing for the two-crop rotation)

Desc: Net income excluding the cost of labor and management.
Notes: Labor and management return/acre for all crop refers to any profit after all out of pocket costs are paid. Computed as Total Revenue + Labor Return - Total Expenses
